newsitem.title: GREECE: UPDATE: ATHENS BOURSE WANTS CLOSER MONITORING OF FIRMS.
newsitem.headline: UPDATE: ATHENS BOURSE WANTS CLOSER MONITORING OF FIRMS.

text.p: The Athens bourse will submit plans for closer monitoring of securities firms to the Stock Exchange Commission, it said in a statement on Thursday.
It will propose a strengthening of the supervisory role of the Board of Directors by creating a special office that will report directly to the board.
The plans follow weeks of turbulence at the bourse after a settlement scandal rocked the exchange to its foundations and stopped trading for four days in November.
Three separate audits are being carried out after the Delta Securities scandal and an investigating magistrate said he had seized 700,000 shares at the bourse clearing house on Tuesday.

Magistrate Constantinos Ganiatsos is investigating the 2.6 billion drachma Securities scandal. Three Delta officials have been charged with fraud after the firm tried to settlement its accounts with bad cheques.
Ganiatsos also said he had asked banks for information on a number of persons suspected of being involved in the scandal.
The scandal and allegations of rampant illegal short-selling at the bourse have helped to cut daily volume to half or less of its normal levels.
Brokers have said that some firms were selling shares short and then taking advantage of the clearing house's heavy backlog to delay settlement and payment.
An offshoot of the scandal has been a tightening of existing measures such as strict inforcement of a 48-hour settlement rule.
This has also caused further upheavals. Delivery in Greece is still of physical paper and brokers have complained that the settlement period is too short.
In recent weeks a number of brokerages have been suspended from trading for a day as the penalty for failing to settle on time with the clearing house.

The bourse announcement on Thursday also said conditions for issuing licences to securities firms should be stricter, while a special license should be required for activities such as consulting and lending.
"These proposals will be submitted to the Stock Exchange Commission, which is responsible for issuing the final decision," the bourse statement said.

It did not say when the proposals would be put to the commission nor when a decision was expected. It gave no further details of what would be contained in the proposals. --Margarita Sotiropoulou, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
